response.answer_text: Original question: “Are written novels dead?” Do you mean “are they a thing of the past and will disappear soon”? If so, then, no. Although libraries are sadly falling to budget cuts all over the world (yes, here in Switzerland, too), small local bookshops are struggling not because of a lack of books, but because of the competition of large chains of bookshops and of course Amazon. However, people still buy books and will continue to do so. Books work offline. Books can’t run out of battery charge. You can pass a book on to a friend to read once you’re done. And you can collect books to fill your bookshelves. So, no. If you mean “Are written books not alive”? Hmmm… Speaking from the perspective of a writer who has published a little (with limited success, but I did it for fun anyway, so I’m happy), I can say that I personally had a weird feeling that the book was “alive” in a way that it difficult to describe. It’s easy to imagine that a writer is omnipotent and can twist and bend a story to unfold exactly as they plan it. But in my case, this was strangely difficult. Whole chapters of my book seemed to write themselves. Others resisted when I tried to change them, and I suddenly felt as if I was struggling to write a boring essay at school, until I gave up and “went with the flow”. Then the text started flowing again, and it sounded and felt completely different than my attempt to change the story. So I certainly felt that the story had developed a sort of life of its own. Also, when you publish a book, It feels oddly like seeing a child move out. Once it’s published, the book is no longer private. It’s no longer “yours”. It becomes something separate. And readers may interpret thing differently than you intended them. You have to learn to accept other interpretations as valid. As the writer, you have the right to say: “Oh, that’s an interesting approach. When I wrote it, I was thinking along different lines. I thought XYZ. But yours is an interesting idea. Thanks for that.” But you have no right to say another interpretation is “wrong”, unless you can demonstrate that logically. So when a book goes public, it develops a life of its own in a different sense. It “evolves” with feedback, with criticism, with questions readers ask. So in both senses, no. Written novels are not dead.

No, but I hope that the e-books would live up to their full potential. Gramarye Media Yes, the CEO is my internet friend. No, I am not getting anything for promoting his company. Anyway, stories had been a part of the human culture for the very long time now. The first ones were presented, told, sung, drawn. Writing helped to preserve them and to reach larger audiences. I don’t see writing as the meaning of creation and recording disappearing any time soon.

God, I hope not! My first novel is coming out in 2017. (And just to make it clear, it was written. Is there another way to create a novel other than by writing it, or at least dictating it to someone else who writes what you say down?) And, let me assure you, it’s a humdinger. You should read some of the blurbs I’ve already gotten. (Of course, you know how reliable blurbs are?)

I really don’t think so, because if they were, then why would they be so prevalent? Bookstores would not exist, there would be no books for sale in grocery stores or big box stores, you could, literally, not buy them at all if they were dead.
Written books are technically dead. They’re at least partially made from pulp, which comes from trees and other living plants. They’re killed to make the book, so yes, they’re dead.
